children.value: Demo
Suppose we want to find a root of the function

f(x) = x * exp(x) - 2
plot(f, 0, 1.5; 
    label="function",  legend=:topleft,
    grid=:y,  ylim=[-2, 4],  xlabel=L"x",  ylabel=L"y")
From the graph, it is clear that there is a root near

children.html: x=1x=1x=1

children.value: . So we call that our initial guess,

children.html: x1x_1x1â

children.value:
xâ = 1
yâ = f(xâ)
scatter!([xâ], [yâ], label="initial point")
Next, we can compute the tangent line at the point
\bigl(x_1,f(x_1)\bigr)
children.html: (x1,f(x1))\bigl(x_1,f(x_1)\bigr)(x1â,f(x1â))

children.value: , using the derivative.

df_dx(x) = exp(x) * (x + 1)
mâ = df_dx(xâ)
tangent = x -> yâ + mâ * (x - xâ)

plot!(tangent, 0, 1.5, l=:dash, label="tangent line",
    title="Tangent line approximation")
In lieu of finding the root of
f
children.html: fff

children.value: itself, we settle for finding the root of the tangent line approximation, which is trivial. Call this

children.html: x2x_2x2â

children.value: , our next approximation to the root.

@show xâ = xâ - yâ / mâ
scatter!([xâ], [0], label="tangent root", title="First iteration")
yâ = f(xâ)
The residual (i.e., value of
f
children.html: fff

children.value: ) is smaller than before, but not zero. So we repeat the process with a new tangent line based on the latest point on the curve.

plot(f, 0.82, 0.87;
    label="function",  legend=:topleft,
    xlabel=L"x",  ylabel=L"y",
    title="Second iteration")

scatter!([xâ], [yâ], label="starting point")

mâ = df_dx(xâ)
tangent = x -> yâ + mâ * (x - xâ)
plot!(tangent, 0.82, 0.87; l=:dash, label="tangent line")

@show xâ = xâ - yâ / mâ
scatter!([xâ], [0], label="tangent root")
yâ = f(xâ)
Judging by the residual, we appear to be getting closer to the true root each time.
